original.definition: play the cards of (a suit) so that the last trick on which a hand can follow suit will be taken by a higher card in the hand of a partner who has the remaining cards of a combined holding

sememes.reasoning: The verb 'unblock' inherently describes the action of removing or causing the cessation of an obstruction or impediment, thereby changing a state from 'blocked' to 'unblocked' within the strategic context of a card game.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' in the frame who intentionally performs the action of unblocking.
The 'something' being unblocked, which refers to a specific suit of cards or the strategic play of those cards within the game.

The definition explicitly states the purpose: 'so that the last trick... will be taken by a higher card in the hand of a partner', indicating the goal of the unblocking action is to enable a partner's success.

Evidentiality.reasoning: The act of unblocking cards in a game is a directly observed action.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating an action or event.

Modality.reasoning: The 'Somebody' performing the action implies a deliberate and willful choice in the game strategy.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of unblocking itself is a neutral strategic move; its positive or negative impact depends on the game context.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody unblock something' clearly indicates a volitional agent ('Somebody') intentionally performing the strategic action.

Confidence.reasoning: The act of performing the unblock is described as a definite occurrence.

Iterativity.reasoning: Within a single game of cards, 'unblocking' a specific suit or sequence is typically a single, distinct strategic maneuver.

candidates.description: (cards) the act of throwing out a useless card or of failing to follow suit (gloss match)
a card game in which you play your sevens and other cards in sequence in the same suit as the sevens; you win if you are the first to use all your cards (gloss match)

a gambling card game in which chips are placed on the ace and king and queen and jack of separate suits (taken from a separate deck); a player plays the lowest card of a suit in his hand and successively higher cards are played until the sequence stops; the player who plays a card matching one in the layout wins all the chips on that card (gloss match)
a card game played with a pack of forty-eight cards (two of each suit for high cards); play resembles whist (gloss match)

a form of solitaire that begins with seven piles of cards with the top cards facing up; descending sequences of cards of alternating colors are built on these piles; as aces become available they are placed above the seven piles; the object is to build sequences in suit from ace to king as the remaining cards are dealt out one at a time (gloss match)
(card games) the act of taking a trick with a trump when unable to follow suit (gloss match)
a playing card in the minor suit that has one or more black trefoils on it (gloss match)
a playing card in the minor suit that has one or more red rhombuses on it (gloss match)
a playing card in the major suit that has one or more red hearts on it (gloss match)
the playing card that is the only card in a suit held in a bridge hand as initially dealt (gloss match)
a playing card in the major suit that has one or more black figures on it (gloss match)
(bridge) a playing card with a value sufficiently high to insure taking a trick in a particular suit (gloss match)
playing card in any of four sets of 13 cards in a pack; each set has its own symbol and color (gloss match)
(card games) the suit that has been declared to rank above all other suits for the duration of the hand (gloss match)
a playing card in the suit that has been declared trumps (gloss match)
a mark on a die or on a playing card (shape depending on the suit) (gloss match)
in a hand, the suit having the most cards (gloss match)
a long suit including high cards (gloss match)
